abstractText: The dichromatic number ~ χ(D) of a digraph D is the least integer k for which D has a coloring with k colors such that there is no monochromatic directed cycle in D. The digraphs considered here are finite and may have antiparallel arcs, but no parallel arcs. A digraph D is called k-critical if each proper subdigraph D of D satisfies ~ χ(D) < ~ χ(D) = k. For integers k and n, let −→ ext(k, n) denote the minimum number of arcs possible in a k-critical digraph of order n. It is easy to show that −→ ext(2, n) = n for all n ≥ 2, and −→ ext(3, n) ≥ 2n for all possible n, where equality holds if and only if n is odd and n ≥ 3. As a main result we prove that if n, k and p are integers with n = k+p and 2 ≤ p ≤ k−1, then −→ ext(k, n) = 2( ( n 2 ) −(p+1)), and we give an exact characterisation of k-critical digraphs for which equality holds. This generalizes a result about critical graphs obtained in 1963 by Tibor Gallai. AMS Subject Classification: 05C15

sections.heading: 1 Introduction and main result
sections.text:
This paper is concerned with the coloring problem for directed graphs (shortly digraphs). Digraphs are always assumed to be finite and simple, that is,

no loops and no parallel arcs in the same direction are allowed. However, digraphs may have antiparallel arcs, that is, two arcs with opposite directions between the same pair of vertices. For a digraph D, we denote the vertex set of D by V (D), and the arc set of D by A(D). The number of vertices of D is called the order of D, denoted by |D|. A digraph D with |D| = 0 is said to be empty, in this case we also write D = ∅. A digraph is said to be acyclic if it contains no directed cycle as a subdigraph.
Let D be a digraph. An acyclic k-coloring of D is a map ϕ : V (D) → C with color set C = {1, 2, . . . , k} such that for each color c ∈ C the subdigraph of D induced by the color class ϕ−1(c) = {v ∈ V (D) | ϕ(v) = c} is acyclic. We denote by ACk(D) the set of acyclic k-colorings of D. The dichromatic number of D, denoted by ~χ(D), is the least integer k ≥ 0 for which ACk(D) 6= ∅. This coloring concept for digraphs, introduced in 1982 by Neumann-Lara and Erdős (cf. [10], [24]) generalizes the ordinary coloring concepts for graphs and has been studied in numerous papers until today (cf. [2], [3], [9], [13], [15], [22], [23], [25], [26]).
Let k be a non-negative integer. We call a digraph D critical and kcritical if every proper subdigraph D′ of D satisfies ~χ(D′) < ~χ(D) = k. Note that any digraph D has a critical subdigraph with the same dichromatic number as D. Hence several problems related to the dichromatic number can be reduced to critical digraphs. Critical digraphs were first introduced and investigated by Neumann-Lara [24]. Let −−→ CRI(k) denote the class of k-critical digraphs, and for an integer n, let
−−→ CRI(k, n) = {D ∈ −−→ CRI(k) | |D| = n}.
Note that ~χ(D) = 0 if and only if D = ∅, and ~χ(D) ≤ 1 if and only if
D is acyclic. Consequently, −−→ CRI(0) = {∅}, −−→ CRI(1) = {K1}, and −−→ CRI(2) is the class of directed cycles. In 2014, Bokal, Fijavž, Juvan, Kayll and Mohar [3] proved that the decision problem whether a given digraph D satisfies ~χ(D) ≤ 2 is NP-complete. Hence a characterization of the class −−→ CRI(k) for fixed k ≥ 3 is unlikely. In this paper, we are interested in the extremal function −→ ext(k, n) defined by
−→ ext(k, n) = min{|A(D)| | D ∈ −−→ CRI(k, n)}.
The following theorem, which is the main result of this paper, implies a classical result for critical graphs that was obtained by Gallai [12] in the 1960s.
Main Theorem. Let n, k and p be integers satisfying n = k + p and 2 ≤ p ≤ k − 1. Then −→ ext(k, n) = 2( ( n
2
)
− (p2 + 1)).
We also characterise exactly the digraphs for which equality holds.

sections.heading: 2 Preliminaries
sections.text: Our notation is standard. For integers k and ℓ, let [k, ℓ] = {x ∈ Z | k ≤ x ≤ ℓ}.

sections.heading: 2.1 Notation for graphs and digraphs
sections.text:
The term graph in this paper always refers to a finite undirected graph without multiple edges and without loops. For a graph G, we denote by V (G) and E(G) the vertex set and the edge set of G, respectively. The order of G, denoted by |G|, is the number of vertices of G. If |G| = 0, then G is called the empty graph, briefly G = ∅. As usual, Kn denotes the complete graph of order n, and Cn denotes the cycle of order n with n ≥ 3. A cycle is called odd or even depending on whether its order is odd or even.
For a digraphD we use the following notation. Let u and v be two distinct vertices of D. Then we denote by a = uv the arc a whose initial vertex is u and whose terminal vertex is v; u and v are then said to be the ends of the arc a. The two arcs uv and vu are said to be opposite arcs. We say that u and v are adjacent in D if uv or vu belongs to A(D). If u and v are adjacent in D, we also say that u is a neighbor of v in D, and vice versa. If uv ∈ A(D), then we say that v is an out-neighbor of u and u is an in-neighbor of v. By N+D(v) we denote the set of out-neighbors of v; by N−D(v) the set of in-neighbors of v. Then d + D(v) = |N +
D(v)| is the out-degree of v in D, and d−D(v) = |N −
D (v)| is the in-degree of v in D. Given X, Y ⊆ V (D), let AD(X, Y ) = {a ∈ A(D) | a = uv, u ∈ X, v ∈ Y }. We denote by D[X ] the subdigraph of D that is induced by the vertex set X , that is, V (D[X ]) = X and A(D[X ]) = AD(X,X). A digraph D
′ is called an induced subdigraph of D if D′ = D[V (D′)]. If X is a subset of V (D), then we define D − X = D[V (D) \ X ]. If X = {v} is a singleton, we use D − v rather than D −X . For an arc set F ⊆ A(D), let D − F denote the subdigraph of D with vertex set V (D) and arc set A(D) \F . If F = {a} is a singleton, we write D− a instead of D− F . We say that D is a ~Cn if D is a
directed cycle of order (length) n, respectively a directed n-cycle, where n ≥ 2. A digraph D is called acyclic if D contains no directed cycle as a subdigraph.
A complete biorientation of a graph G is a digraph that can be obtained from G by replacing each edge e of G by two opposite arcs with the same ends as e, we denote the resulting digraph by D±(G). SoD±(K1) = K1, and D±(K2) = ~C2 is a directed cycle of order 2, such a digraph is also refereed to as a digon. An orientation of a graph G is a digraph D obtained from G by directing every edge of G from one of its ends to the other one. An orientation of a graph is also called an oriented graph. Note that a digraph is an oriented graph if and only if it is digon-free.

sections.heading: 2.2 Coloring of graphs and digraphs
sections.text: Let G be a graph. An independent k-coloring of G is a map ϕ : V (G) → [1, k] such that for each color c ∈ [1, k] the color class ϕ−1(c) = {v ∈ V (G) | ϕ(v) = c} is an independent set of G, that is, the subgraph of G induced by ϕ−1(c) is edgeless. Let ICk(G) denote the set of independent kcolorings of G. Then the chromatic number of G, denoted by χ(G), is the least integer k for which ICk(G) 6= ∅. Clearly, χ(G) = 0 if and only if G = ∅; and χ(G) ≤ 1 if and only if G is edgeless. A graph G with χ(G) ≤ 2 is also referred to as a bipartite graph. By a result of König it is known that a graph G is bipartite if and only if G contains no odd cycle. However, the decision problem whether a given graph G satisfies χ(G) ≤ 3 is NP-complete. If G is a graph and D = D±(G), then V (G) = V (D) = V and a map ϕ : V → [1, k] is an independent coloring of G if and only if ϕ is an acyclic coloring of D. Consequently, every graph G satisfies χ(G) = ~χ(D±(G)).

sections.heading: 2.3 Minimum number of edges in critical graphs
sections.text:
Deleting a vertex or edge of a graph decreases its chromatic number by at most one. Let k be a non-negative integer. A graph G is called critical and k-critical if every proper subgraph G′ of G satisfies χ(G′) < χ(G) = k. Let CRI(k) denote the class of k-critical graphs, and for n ≥ 0, let
CRI(k, n) = {G ∈ CRI(k) | |G| = n}.
Clearly, if G ∈ CRI(k), then |G| ≥ k and equality holds if and only if G = Kk. For k ≤ 2, Kk is the only k-critical graph. In particular, CRI(0) = {∅},
CRI(1) = {K1}, and CRI(2) = {K2}. Furthermore, König’s theorem about bipartite graphs implies that
CRI(3) = {Cn | n ≡ 1 (mod 2)}.
A good characterization of CRI(k) with fixed k ≥ 4 is very unlikely. It is known that if k ≥ 4, then CRI(k, n) 6= ∅ if and only if n ≥ k and n 6= k+1. The concept of critical graphs is due to G. A. Dirac. In the 1950s he established the basic properties of critical graphs in a series of papers (see [5], [6] and [7]), and the study of critical graphs has attracted a lot of attention since then. Dirac also started to investigate the function ext(k, n) defined by
ext(k, n) = min{|E(G)| | G ∈ CRI(k, n)}
as well as the corresponding class
EXT(k, n) = {G ∈ CRI(k, n) | |E(G)| = ext(k, n)}
of extremal graphs. For a detailed discussion of the many partial results related to this extremal function the reader is referred to the survey by Kostochka [18] (see also [21]).
It is easy to show that every graph in CRI(k) with k ≥ 1 has minimum degree at least k−1, which gives the trivial lower bound 2ext(k, n) ≥ (k−1)n. By Brooks’ famous theorem [4] it follows that 2ext(k, n) = (k − 1)n if and only if n = k or k = 3 and n is odd. In 1957 Dirac [7] (see also [8]) proved that 2ext(k, n) ≥ (k − 1)n + k − 3 for every k ≥ 4 and n ≥ k + 2. For k ≥ 3, we denote by DG(k) the class of graphs that can be obtained from two disjoints Kk’s by splitting a vertex of one Kk into an edge of the other Kk. So a graph G belongs to DG(k) if and only if the vertex set of G consists of three non-empty pairwise disjoint sets X, Y1 and Y2 with
|Y1|+ |Y2| = |X|+ 1 = k − 1
and two additional vertices v1 and v2 such that G[X ] and G[Y1 ∪ Y2] are complete graphs not joined by any edge in G, and X∪Yi is the neighborhood of vi in G for i ∈ {1, 2}. Then it is easy to show that DG(k) ⊆ CRI(k, 2k−1). The class DG(k) was introduced and investigated by Dirac [8] and by Gallai [11]. Dirac [8] proved that EXT(k, 2k−1) = DG(k) for every k ≥ 3. In 1963, Gallai published two fundamental papers [11] and [12] about the structure of critical graphs. In particular, he proved the following two remarkable results.
Theorem 2.1 (Gallai 1963). Let G be a k-critical graph of order n. If n ≤ 2k − 2, then the complement of G is disconnected.
Theorem 2.2 (Gallai 1963). Let n = k + p be an integer, where k, p ∈ N and 2 ≤ p ≤ k − 1. Then

sections.heading: 2.4 Minimum number of arcs in critical digraphs
sections.text:
While the study of critical graphs has attracted a lot of attention, not so much is known about the structure of critical digraphs. Neumann-Lara [24] established some basic properties of critical digraphs. The proof of the next result is straightforward and left to the reader.
Proposition 2.3 (Neumann-Lara). Let D ∈ −−→ CRI(k) with k ≥ 1. Then the following statements hold:
(a) If v ∈ V (D) and ϕ ∈ ACk−1(D − v), then for each color c ∈ [1, k] the color class ϕ−1(c) contains an out-neighbor of v and an in-neighbor of v. As a consequence |ϕ(N+D(v))| = |ϕ(N − D(v))| = k − 1.
(b) Each vertex v ∈ V (D) satisfies d+D(v) ≥ k − 1 and d − D(v) ≥ k − 1.
(c) If a = uv ∈ A(D) and ϕ ∈ ACk−1(D − a), then there is a color c ∈ C such that D[ϕ−1(c)] contains a directed path from v to u.
(d) |D| ≥ k and equality holds if and only if D = D±(Kk).
(e) If k = 1, then |D| = 1; and if k = 2, then D is a directed cycle.
Recall that −−→ CRI(0) = {∅}, −−→ CRI(1) = {K1}, and −−→ CRI(2) = { ~Cn | n ≥ 2}.
Given k, n ∈ N, let
−→ ext(k, n) = min{|A(D)| | D ∈ −−→ CRI(k, n)}
and −−→ EXT(k, n) = {D ∈ −−→ CRI(k, n) | |A(D)| = −→ ext(k, n)}.
Mohar [23] established a Brooks-type result for digraphs. Together with Proposition 2.3(b) this leads to some basic information about −→ ext(k, n) and −−→ EXT(k, n). Theorem 2.4 (Mohar). If D ∈ −−→ CRI(k) with k ≥ 2 and d+D(v) = d −
D(v) = k − 1 for all v ∈ V (D), then k = 2 and D is a directed cycle, or k = 3 and D = D±(Cn) with n odd and n ≥ 3, or k ≥ 4 and D = D ±(Kk). Corollary 2.5. Let k, n ∈ N with n ≥ k ≥ 2. Then −→ ext(k, n) ≥ (k − 1)n and equality holds if and only if k = 2 and n ≥ 2, or k = 3 and n ≥ 3 is odd, or n = k ≥ 4. Furthermore, −−→ EXT(2, n) = { ~Cn} for n ≥ 2, −−→ EXT(3, n) = {D±(Cn)} for odd n and n ≥ 3, and −−→ EXT(k, k) = {D±(Kk)} for k ≥ 4.
Let D = D±(G) be a complete biorientation of the graph G. Then it is easy to see that G ∈ CRI(k) if and only if D ∈ −−→ CRI(k). As a consequence, we obtain that −→ ext(k, n) ≤ 2ext(k, n) for n ≥ k ≥ 4 and n 6= k+1. Note that CRI(k, k + 1) = ∅, but −−→ CRI(k, k + 1) 6= ∅ (see Proposition 3.2). Theorem 2.6 (Aboulker and Vermande 2022). Let n > k ≥ 4 and D ∈ −−→ CRI(k, n), then
|A(D)| ≥ (k − 1)n+ k − 3.
Moreover, equality holds if and only if D ∈ −→ DG(k).

sections.heading: 2.5 Decomposable critical digraphs
sections.text:
As pointed out by Bang-Jensen, Bellitto, Schweser, and Stiebitz [2], two well known constructions for critical graphs have counterparts for digraphs, namely the Hajós join and the Dirac join.
Let D1 and D2 be two disjoint digraphs. First we construct a digraph D as follows. For i ∈ {1, 2}, we choose an arc uivi ∈ A(Di). Then let D be the digraph obtained from the union D1 ∪D2 by deleting both arcs u1v1 and v2u2, identifying the vertices v1 and v2 to a new vertex, and adding the new arc u1u2. We say that D is the Hajós join of D1 and D2 and write D = D1∇D2. Furthermore, let D
′ be the digraph obtained from the union D1 ∪ D2 by adding all possible arcs in both directions between D1 and D2,
that is, V (D′) = V (D1)∪V (D2) and A(D) = A(D1)∪A(D2)∪{uv, vu | u ∈ V (D1) and v ∈ V (D2)}. We call D
′ the Dirac join of D1 and D2 and write D′ = D1 ⊞D2. The following result was proved in [2]; a proof of the second result (also mentioned in [2]) is straightforward.
Theorem 2.7 (Hajos Construction). Let D = D1∇D2 be the Hajós join of two disjoint non-empty digraphs D1 and D2, and let k ≥ 3 be an integer. Then D belongs to −−→ CRI(k) if and only if both D1 and D2 belong to −−→ CRI(k).
Theorem 2.8 (Dirac Construction). Let D = D1 ⊞D2 be the Dirac join of two disjoint non-empty digraphs D1 and D2. Then, χ(D) = χ(D1) + χ(D2) and D is critical if and only if both D1 and D2 are critical.
The Hajós construction can be used to establish an upper bound for −→ ext(k, n) for n ≥ k ≥ 3. IfD1 ∈ −−→ EXT(k, n) andD2 ∈ −−→ EXT(k,m) with n,m ≥ k, then D = D1∇D2 ∈ −−→ CRI(k, n+m−1) and |A(D)| = |A(D1)|+|A(D2)|−1, which implies that
−→ ext(k, n+m− 1) ≤ −→ ext(k, n) + −→ ext(k,m)− 1.
By Fekete’s lemma (see also Jensen and Toft [17, Problem 5.3.]), this implies that the limit limn→∞( −→ ext(k, n)/n) exists.
A digraph is called decomposable if it is the Dirac join of two non-empty subdigraphs; otherwise the digraph is called indecomposable. Theorem 2.8 implies that a decomposable critical digraph is the Dirac join of its indecomposable critical subdigraphs. In this sense, the indecomposable critical digraphs are the building elements of critical digraphs. In 2019, Stěhĺık [28] proved the following result, thereby answering a question proposed in [2]. Note that this result applied to bidirected graphs implies the decomposition result for critical graphs due to Gallai (see Theorem 2.1). Stěhĺık’s proof uses matching theory. However, one can also use the hypergraph version of Theorem 2.1 obtained by Stiebitz, Storch and Toft [27].
Theorem 2.9 (Stehĺık 2019). If D is an indecomposable critical digraph, then |D| ≥ 2~χ(D)− 1.
Sketch of Proof : Let D ∈ −−→ CRI(k) with |D| ≤ 2k − 2. Our aim is to show that D is decomposable. Let H be a hypergraph with V (H) = V (D) such that e ⊆ V (H) is an edge of H if and only if D[e] is a directed cycle.
Note that no edge of H contains another edge of H . Then χ(H) = k and χ(H− v) < k for every vertex v of H . Then H has a subhypergraph H ′ such that χ(H ′′) < χ(H ′) = χ(H) = k for every proper subhypergraph H ′′ of H ′. Furthermore, we have that V (H ′) = V (H). Then, by [27, Main Theorem 1], H ′ is obtained from the disjoint union of two nonempty subhypergraphs by adding all 2-edges between these two subhypergraphs. Since e is a 2-edge of H if and only if D[e] is a digon, we obtain that D is decomposable.
The complement of a digraph D, denoted by D, is the digraph with V (D) = V (D) and A(D) = {uv | uv 6∈ A(D)}. So if D has order n, then D∪D = D±(Kn). Clearly, a non-empty digraph D is indecomposable if and only if D is connected.

sections.heading: 3 Critical digraphs whose order is near to ~χ
sections.text:
LetD be a digraph. A non-empty subdigraphD′ ofD is called a dominating subdigraph of D if there exists a non-empty subdigraph D′′ of D such that D = D′ ⊞ D′′. A vertex v of D is called a dominating vertex of D if the subdigraph D[{v}] is a dominating subdigraph of D. Note that if X ⊆ V (D) is a set of p ≥ 0 vertices such that any vertex of X is a dominating vertex of D, then D = D±(Kp)⊞ (D −X).
Theorem 3.1. Let D be a k-critical digraph with k ≥ 1, let p be the number of dominating vertices of D, and q be the number of dominating directed cycles of D having order at least three. Then the following statements hold:
(a) 0 ≤ p ≤ k and there exists a digraph D′ ∈ −−→ CRI(k − p) such that
D = D±(Kp)⊞D ′, D′ has no dominating vertex, and |D′| ≥ 3 2 (k − p). Furthermore, p ≥ 3k − 2|D| and equality holds if and only if D′ is the Dirac join of 1
2 (k − p) disjoint directed 3-cycles of D.
(b) 0 ≤ p + 2q ≤ k and there exist digraphs D1 ∈ −−→ CRI(2q) and D2 ∈
−−→ CRI(k − p − 2q) such that D = D±(Kp) ⊞ D1 ⊞ D2, D1 is the Diracjoin of q directed cycles of D each of which has order at least three, D2 has no dominating vertex and no dominating directed cycle, and |D2| ≥ 5
3 (k − p − 2q). Furthermore, 2p + q ≥ 5k − 3|D| and equality
holds if and only if D1 is the Dirac-join of q directed 3-cycles of D, and D2 is the Dirac-join of 1
3 (k − p− 2q) disjoint subdigraphs of D each of
which belong to −−→ CRI(3, 5).
Proof. In what follows, let D ∈ −−→ CRI(k) with k ≥ 1. Then D is a connected digraph and it follows from Theorem 2.9 that
D = D1 ⊞D2 ⊞ · · ·⊞Ds,

In the remaining of this section, we discuss some consequences of Theorem 3.1.
For a digraph K and a class of digraphs D, define K⊞D = {K⊞D | D ∈ D} if D 6= ∅, and K ⊞ D = ∅ otherwise. Theorem 4.1 applied to bidirected graphs gives Gallai’s result (Theorem 2.2). Gallai’s original proof was much longer, since he did not use Dirac’s result from 1974. On the other hand, Gallai’s result combined with the Kotochka–Yancey bound for ext(k, n) implies Dirac’s result, since the Kostochka–Yancey bound is better that the Dirac bound if n ≥ 2k.
